info.game_comments:
2000 Tournament of Champions quarterfinal game 1. 
From the Atlanta Civic Center.

jeopardy_round: THE GONE WITH THE WIND MOVIE MUSEUM

(1, 1).clue: The "History's Mysteries" program did a show on this June 1944 event, "The Best Kept Secret"

(2, 1).clue: In 1998 he was named MVP of the NBA, MVP of the All-Star Game & MVP of the NBA finals

(3, 1).clue: Chimps & gorillas are classified as "great" ones

(4, 1).clue: The apartment house she lived in while writing the novel is adjacent to the museum

(5, 1).clue: This author said that he would have offered the savage a third alternative if he were to rewrite "Brave New World"

(6, 1).clue: It's a return to former popularity; John Travolta made one in "Pulp Fiction"

(1, 2).clue: It's the New Deal organization that's the subject of the program seen here:"The plan--tame the river with dozens of dams & 200,000 workers"

(2, 2).clue: She dominated women's figure skating in 1992 by winning the U.S., World & Olympic championships

(4, 2).clue: One of the museum's most treasured movie artifacts is the front doorway of this plantation, Scarlett's home

(5, 2).clue: A translator's introduction to this novel says that Dostoyevsky was, "Like Raskolnikov, up to the neck in debt"

(6, 2).clue: Oddly, this group's album "Millennium" was released in 1999

(1, 3).clue: Part history, part fashion, "Battle of the Clans" tells of these patterns banned in the 18th century

(2, 3).clue: In the 1990s this Seattle Mariner led the AL in home runs 4 times, more than any other player in the decade

(4, 3).clue: The museum is part of a 2-block historic district on this Atlanta street

(5, 3).clue: He said that freelance photography helped pay the bills while he wrote "Invisible Man"

(6, 3).clue: Eric Stoltz was originally cast as Marty McFly in this 1985 comedy

(1, 4).clue: This designer's Y-line dress, seen here, highlighted a show on the year 1955

(2, 4).clue: The Pittsburgh Penguins' No. 1 draft pick in 1984, he played his last NHL game on April 26, 1997

(3, 4).clue: Used of pythons, it means "having a net-like pattern"

(4, 4).clue: Scarlett was often laced up into one of these undergarments, & one of them is on display

(5, 4).clue: In the foreword to her 1818 novel, she recalls a trip to Switzerland & a ghost story contest with Lord Byron

(6, 4).clue: This phrase, an acknowledgement of failure, implies that an architect or a designer must create new plans

(1, 5).clue: A program on ocean liners featured this ship, seen here:"She could carry 3,000 passengers & crew in unparalleled comfort..."

(2, 5).clue: (Hi, I'm Steve Smith of the NBA.)  My boyhood idol, George Gervin, had this nickname because he always kept his cool

(3, 5).clue: An informal word meaning "arrested", or a type of peccary

(4, 5).clue: You can see the broken vase Scarlett threw when this character she loved spurned her at Twelve Oaks

(5, 5).clue: This 1955 novel's foreword says, "I have no intention to glorify 'H.H.'....he is a shining example of moral leprosy"

(6, 5).clue: This 1979 miniseries glimpsed at the private lives of 8 presidential families, as seen by their maids & butlers

(2, 1).clue: On "20/20", Hugh Downs once did a segment on Fess Parker, who played this famous ancestor of Downs

(3, 1).clue: "Biggest" & "best" are examples of this, one degree above a comparative

(4, 1).clue: These, the symbol for Libra, may appear alone or with a woman holding them

(5, 1).clue: Now a term for a political obstructionary tactic, it comes from a Dutch word meaning "pirate"

(6, 1).clue: Traditionally, presidents have taken the oath of office in front of this building

(2, 2).clue: It's only natural that Patricia Cornwell became a writer; she's a descendant of this "Uncle Tom's Cabin" author

(3, 2).clue: From the Latin for "to fill", many were "deleted" from the Watergate transcripts

(4, 2).clue: This bovine is Zeus in disguise, which makes it Zeus in da skies

(5, 2).clue: North American city that's home to the Festival International de Jazz & the Festival International de Nouvelle Danse

(6, 2).clue: The presidential library system formally began in 1939 when this man donated his papers to the federal government

(2, 3).clue: Tom Hanks' family tree includes Nancy Hanks, the mother of this president

(3, 3).clue: A newly needed specific name is a retronym, like this type of "guitar" after electric ones came in

(4, 3).clue: This one of the 12 signs is the subject of the first of the 12 labors of Hercules

(5, 3).clue: In 1926 the novel "Lolly Willowes" became the first selection this club sent to its members

(6, 3).clue: The presidential seal features an eagle with arrows in its left talon & this in its right representing peace

(2, 4).clue: Anna, of "Anna And The King Of Siam", was the great aunt of this legendary horror star, on his "mummy's" side

(3, 4).clue: Sometimes called $64 words, by definition they have multiple speech segments, usually 4 or more

(4, 4).clue: Before it was fleeced, it could fly; Helle fell from it into what's now the Hellespont

(5, 4).clue: In 1965 the highest grossing movie of all time was "The Sound of Music"; 10 years later it was this 1975 film

(6, 4).clue: The 22nd Amendment, limiting a president to 2 terms, was ratified during this man's presidency

(2, 5).clue: As you might gather from her name, Lee Meriwether is related to this explorer

(3, 5).clue: It's an adverb, like "very", that increases the force of the word it modifies

(4, 5).clue: This symbol represents Ganymede, who was abducted to work on Olympus

(5, 5).clue: Thomas Paine was indicted for treason in England in 1792 for this work defending the French Revolution

(6, 5).clue: To protect "our most important national investment", I signed a bill creating this cabinet department in 1979

(0, 0).clue: Before Congress named it for a person, its residents wanted to call it the territory of Columbia
